Title: First Order Linear Differential Equations

Content.Text:
For an equation 
we can multiply both sides by an integrating factor u(t):
Equations: \left( e^{\int p(t) \, dt} y \right)' = e^{\int p(t) \, dt} g(t)
e^{\int p(t) \, dt} y = \int e^{\int p(t) \, dt} g(t) \, dt + C
y = \frac{\int e^{\int p(t) \, dt} g(t) \, dt + C}{e^{\int p(t) \, dt}}
u(t) = e^{\int \frac{t+1}{t} \, dt} = e^{\int (1 + \frac{1}{t}) \, dt} = t e^t

Content.Text: Assume solution to previous equation takes initial condition y(1) = a. Describe solution's behavior for t > 0 when a = \frac{2}{e}. Plug in t = 1, y = a:

Diagrams.Description: A graph showing the behavior of the solution.
Diagrams.Interpretation: The graph demonstrates that as t approaches 0, the solution tends to infinity, and as t approaches infinity, the solution tends to 0.

Summary: This lecture covers the general solution of first-order linear differential equations, an example problem, and the behavior of the solution under certain initial conditions.
